task.title: Create Load Balancer
task.shortdesc: This wizard allows you to create a new load balancer. A load balancer allows you to automatically balance incoming traffic among a predefined group of instances, ensuring that requests are sent to an instance that has the capacity to serve them. For more information on load balancers, please see Using Elastic Load Balancing in the Eucalyptus User Guide.

task.title: General
task.shortdesc: This section is where you specify the basic configuration of your new load balancer.

step.cmd: Type the name of your load balancer in the Name text box.

A listener is the definition of ports (client-side and instance-side) and protocols that the load balancer uses to monitor and route incoming traffic to the load balancer's registered instances. To define one or more listeners for your load balancer:

substep.cmd: Type the number for the client-side port into the CLIENT-SIDE PORT text box.
Select the protocol for this listener from the PROTOCOL (CLIENT-SIDE to INSTANCE-SIDE) drop-down list box.
Type the number for the client-side port into the INSTANCE-SIDE PORT text box.
You can add another listener by click on the plus icon next to the INSTANCE-SIDE PORT text box.

step.cmd: When you are done with the General section, click the Next: Define membership button to continue.

task.title: Membership
task.shortdesc: This section allows you to add running instances to your new load balancer.

step.cmd: Select the name of the load balancer to which you want to add instances from the Load balancer name drop-down list.

step.note: You can select one or more filters by pressing the enter key or clicking on the search bar and selecting an available filter from the drop down list. Selecting some filters will expose a menu with a list of valid filter values that you can select by pressing the enter key or clicking the value.
step.cmd: Select the check box next to the instances that you want to add from the list of running instances.

You can optionally control traffic for one or more scaling groups by selecting a scaling group from the Also use this load balancer to control traffic for these scaling groups drop-down list box, using the plus icon to add more than one scaling group.
Click the Next: Configure health check button to continue.

task.title: Membership
task.shortdesc: This section allows you to define a health check for your load balancer instances. The health check includes a port, protocol, and URL path to query to ensure that an instance is running and healthy.

step.cmd: Define the ping settings for the health check:

substep.cmd: Select the protocol from the Protocol drop-down list box.
Type the port number to use for the health check ping in the Port number text box.
Define the path that the health check query should ping by typing it into the Path text box.
Specify the number of seconds before the health check query times out by typing a number into the Response timeout (seconds) text box.
Specify the number of minutes before the health check pings by typing a number into the Time betwen pings (min) text box.

step.cmd: Define the instance thresholds for the health check.

substep.cmd: Specify the number of failed ping attempts until an instance is considered unhealthy by selecting a number from the Failures until unhealthy drop-down list box.

Specify the number of successful ping attempts until an instance that was previously marked as unhealthy is considered healthy again by selecting a number from the Passes until unhealthy drop-down list box.

step.cmd: Once you've reviewed and are satisfied with your load balancer configuration, click the Create load balancer button to create your new load balancer.
